content:
JAPAN

ANA Holdings (9202 JT) - Co. H1 net JPY 56.7bln vs. Prev. JPY 73.7bln Y/Y, cuts FY net forecasts. (Newswires)

Capcom (9697 JT) - Co. H1 net JPY 9.85bln vs. Prev. JPY 6.85bln Y/Y. (Newswires)

Fujitsu (6702 JT) - Co. H1 net JPY 63.7bln vs. Prev. JPY 81.1bln Y/Y, raises FY net forecast. (Newswires)

GS Yuasa (6674 JT) - Co. raised H1 oper. profit forecast to JPY 7.5bln from JPY 5.0bln. (Newswires)

Hitachi (6501 JT) - Co. is planning to merge auto part companies with Honda. (Newswires)

Honda (7267 JT) - Toyota (7203 JT) is said to purchase Honda business jet for executives’ travel. (Newswires)

Keihin (7251 JT) - Tokyo Exchange suspends shares in Keihin, Nissin Kogyo (7230 JT) and Showa Corp (7274 JT) following merger report. (Newswires)

Mitsui & Co. (8031 JT) - Co. confirmed it will offload interest in C2C Power Wind & Solar Power Generation. (Newswires)

Nissan (7201 JT) - Co. reportedly failed to pay tax on JPY 150mln booked business expenditures. (Nikkei)

Nomura Holdings (8604 JT) - Co. H1 net JPY 194.4bln vs. Prev. loss JPY 6.0bln Y/Y. (Newswires)

NTT DoCoMo (9437 JT) - Co. H1 net JPY 372.4bln vs. Prev. JPY 407.1bln Y/Y, Co. affirms FY net but lowers rev. guidance. (Newswires)

Omron (6645 JT) - Nidec (6594 JT) to acquire OMRON Automotive Electronics. (Newswires)

Osaka Gas (9532 JT) - Co. H1 net JPY 33.5bln vs. Prev. JPY 13.5bln Y/Y. (Newswires)

Sony (6758 JT) - Co. is to invest JPY 100bln in semiconductor factory to boost domestic image sensor production. (Nikkei)

Food Producers - EU is to relax restrictions on Japanese food products that were placed after the Fukushima nuclear plant disaster, with the restrictions to be eased from November 14th. (Newswires)

Other News - BoJ will start lending shares in ETFs to brokerages as early as next spring to try to restore some of the liquidity it has drained out of the market via its massive monetary easing program. (Nikkei)

 

 

SOUTH KOREA

Doosan Heavy (034020 KS) - Co. will repurchase and cancel KRW 415.8bln of redeemable convertible preference shares. (Newswires)

LG Innotek (011070 KS) - Co. Q3 net KRW 124.9bln vs. Prev. KRW 93.7bln Y/Y. (Newswires)

Samsung Engineering (028050 KS) - Co. Q3 net KRW 72.7bln vs. Exp. KRW 66.8bln. (Newswires)

Samsung Group - Samsung is likely to take part in Saudi Arabia’s large entertainment city construction project. (Yonhap)

Other News - South Korea Unification Ministry says North Korea believes it is unnecessary to conduct separate working-level meeting to discuss removal of South Korea facilities from Mount Kumgang. (Newswires)

subject: ASIAN DAILY ECONOMIC RELEASES CALENDAR NOW AVAILABLE IN THE RESEARCH SECTION: Highlights include Japanese Retail Sales and Australian CPI
DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
ASIA-PAC

US President Trump and China President Xi are reportedly set for November 17th meeting in Chile to sign interim trade deal, according to a source cited by SCMP. (SCMP)

US official said US-China Phase 1 deal may not be signed at the Chile APEC meeting in November but progress is being made and that if a deal is not signed in Chile it does not mean the talks have fallen apart, just that more time is needed. The official added our goal is to sign it in Chile but sometimes texts are not ready. Furthermore, the official noted that good progress is being made and that they expect to sign the agreement in Chile, while a White House Spokesperson also said the sides are working to finalise the text of a phase one trade deal for signing in Chile. (Newswires)

BoJ will start lending shares in ETF's to brokerages as early as next spring to try to restore some of the liquidity it has drained out of the market via its massive monetary easing program. (Nikkei) 

 

UK/EU

UK lawmakers approved the early election bill with 438 votes and 20 against for an election on December 12th with the date for Parliament dissolution set on November 6th. Proposals for lowering the voting age or allowing EU citizens to vote were not included for debate, while amendment to change the election date to December 9th was selected for debate but voted against by Parliament. (Newswires)

UK government reportedly began restoring the whip to 10 of the Tory 21 group on Tuesday. (Times/Twitter)

EU Council President Tusk tweeted the EU27 has formally adopted the extension and that it may be the last one, while he added to please make the best use of this time. (Twitter)

EU's Dombrovskis said European Commission is not considering an option of asking Italy to amend its 2020 budget. (Newswires)

 

FX

SNB expanded Board Member Schlegel said monetary policy is not the only factor for low interest rates and that, in real terms, the value of the CHF is where it was before minimum rate was ended, while Schlegel added it is clear that Switzerland is dependent on the situation abroad and will assess constantly. (Newswires)

 

COMMODITIES

API Energy Inventories Crude +0.59mln (exp. +0.5mln, Prev. +4.51mln), although other social media reports suggested contradicting figures of a 1.7mln bbl drawdown to crude inventories and newswires are yet to confirm the figures. (Newswires)

 

US

US President Trump reiterated familiar criticisms of the Fed and agreed with a comment that suggested the US should follow EU and Japan to have negative rates, while he added the Fed is holding US economy back but added we are still winning. (Twitter)

Moody's said there are concerns that the Fed does not have enough ammunition to address the next recession given the lower long-run Federal funds rate. (Newswires)

US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin said he is open to looser bank rules in order to help alleviate repo market stress. (Newswires)

  • US Consumer Confidence (Oct) 125.9 vs. Exp. 128.0 (Prev. 125.1). (Newswires)
  • US Pending Sales Change MM (Sep) 1.5% vs. Exp. 0.9% (Prev. 1.6%, Rev. 1.4%)

 

MARKET RECAP

Fiat Chrysler (FCAU) had a late day spike into the green after the WSJ reported it was in talks with Peugeot (UG FP) for a USD 50bln merger. Tesla (TSLA) sold off on its 10-Q filing where investors scrutinised its reporting, particularly the decline in quarterly domestic sales; Roth downgraded the stock to Sell citing warranty adjustments as a large driver of the margin beat, something that is unsustainable. Mirati Therapeutics (MRTX) spiked on a positive data from tumour treatment, MRTX849. PG&E (PCG) pared some of its heavy losses as it restored power to more customers. Walmart (WMT) was the victim of Amazon’s (AMZN) free grocery delivery for Prime members announcement. Apache (APA) traded higher after a Sector Weight initiation at KeyBanc, citing an improving growth story. S&P 500 -0.1% at 3037, NASDAQ-100 -0.8% at 8048, Dow Jones -0.1% at 27071.

Albeit thin ranges, the TPLEX made headway as investors grew cautious amid talk of a delay to the US-China Phase 1 deal. The (small) lion’s share of the move came in the European session when major equity bourses began their trundle lower in anticipation of key risk events. There was a ramp up of corporate issuance on Tuesday, with ten issuers scheduled to hit the primary IG market - including a USD 4bln M&A bond from Danaher (DHR) - potentially providing resistance to the wider debt complex. At settlement the curve was fractionally flatter with the 10-year yield down 1.8bps and the 2-year yield down 0.8bps, with participants now looking towards the FOMC on Wednesday. US T-notes (Z9) settled 3+ ticks higher at 129-08+.

subject: RANsquawk US Market Wrap - 29th October 2019: Markets tentative ahead of FOMC tomorrow and NFP on Friday
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • SNAPSHOT: Equities flat/lower, Treasuries flat/higher, crude lower, dollar flat
  • REAR VIEW: Phase 1 US/China trade deal may not be signed at APEC next month, Mnuchin open to looser bank rules to alleviate repo stress, EU not considering asking Italy to amend budget. UK to head to the polls
  • COMING-UP: Data; Australian CPI, French GDP (Prelim), German Unemployment Change & CPI (Prelim), EZ Economic, Industrial & Services Sentiment and Consumer Confidence; US GDP (Advanced), Events; FOMC and BoC Rate Decisions & Press Conference, Speakers; ECB's Lautenschlager, Supply; Italy and Germany, Earnings; Apple, Facebook, General Electric, Bayer, Volkswagen, Total, Deutsche Bank, Iberdrola.

* US/CHINA TRADE: US official said that a US/China Phase one deal may not be signed at the Chile APEC meeting in November as more time is needed. Officials did caveat, however, that progress is being still being made and if a deal is not signed in Chile it does not mean the talks have fallen apart, just that more time is needed. The news was initially taken negatively (a fleeting risk-off move was triggered). The report added, that US’ goal was “to sign it in Chile. But sometimes texts are not ready. But good progress is being made and we expect to sign the agreement in Chile."

* PREVIEW: FOMC rate decision (October 2019) - The Fed is expected to lower rates by 25bps to 1.50-1.75%; key will be whether the Committee signals that it is now on pause, or whether the door to further cuts remains open. While market pricing and the analyst consensus are looking for a rate cut, some have warned that there may be enough for the Fed to pause at this meeting. The FOMC will publish its rate decision on 31st October 2019 at 1800 GMT/1400 EDT. Post-meeting press conference with Fed Chair Powell scheduled for 1830 GMT/1430 EDT. To download the report, please click here.

* MNUCHIN: US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin said he is open to looser bank rules in order to help alleviate repo market stress. The news saw stocks break above yesterday’s high and print fresh all-time highs (SPX printed 3047 in wake of Mnuchin’s comments).

* PREVIEW: BOC rate decision (October 2019) - The Bank of Canada is expected to keep rates unchanged; incoming data has given the Bank scope to remain upbeat, however, extended market pricing may underestimate the scope for a dovish statement. It is an MPR meeting, which will likely see 2019 GDP forecasts raised, though 2020 is uncertain. The BOC will publish its rate decision on 30th October 2019 at 1400 GMT/1000 EDT. Post-meeting press conference with Governor Powell and Deputy Governor Wilkins scheduled for 1515 GMT/1115 EDT. To download the report, please click here.

* BREXIT: UK government wins the vote for an early General Election on December 12th with 438 votes for, and 20 against. The earlier amendment for a date change to the 9th December, was rejected which now sends the UK to the polls on the 12th. Labour argued that the 9th would allow university students to vote where they are registered, but Conservatives did not believe that the 9th provided enough time to pass the bill through. Recent polling has seen labour slacking recently with the latest YouGov poll putting them at 22% and Conservatives at 37%. The FT tracker, which combines the polls, has conservatives leading with 35%, followed by labour at 25%, Lib Dems at 18%, Brexit Party at 11% and SNP/PC at 4%. However, the % of national votes do not necessarily translate into the seats acquired unless that individual seat is won, therefore eyeing the trend of polls may be more appropriate.

* US CONSUMER CONFIDENCE: Consumer confidence fell in October, from a prior revised 126.3 to 125.9, missing expectations for a rise to 128. The print was within analyst expectations, however. which ranged from lows of 120 to highs of 132. The differentials between jobs plentiful and jobs hard to get picked up from 33.2 to 35.1, auguring well for the US jobless rate. Some analysts also note that, the UoM’s Sentiment gauge for October also ticked lower, missing expectations, a potential concern since consumer confidence has now fallen for three consecutive months. Pantheon Macroeconomics notes that the trend is now probably declining and it expects “slowing payroll growth gradually to depress consumers’ sentiment through the late fall and winter, but it’s hard to expect it to plunge as long as the stock market is resilient and gas prices are low”. The consultancy also notes that the declining trend is not surprising due to the ongoing trade war, adding that consumers have not yet directly reacted to the tariffs on consumer goods.

* US PENDING HOME SALES: Pending home sales rose by 1.5% in September, exceeding the consensus 0.9%; On a Y/Y basis, pending home sales are running at a clip of 6.3%, the strongest rate in four years. Pantheon Macroeconomics said that the rising trend in the index means that the hit to existing home sales from last year’s capping of state and local tax deductions has now reversed; the rebound in sales is tracking the upturn in mortgage demand, which Pantheon suggests points to new cycle highs for home sales over the next few months. 

* ITALY: EU's Dombrovskis said that the European Commission is not considering an option of asking Italy to amend its 2020 budget. One week ago, sources noted that the European Commission had asked Italy for “clarifications” over its 2020 budget, as such, one would assume concerns have been addressed (for now).

* CLOSING LEVELS: S&P 500 -0.1% at 3037, NASDAQ-100 -0.8% at 8048, Dow Jones  -0.1% at 27071

* S&P 500 SECTORS: Consumer Discretionary  -0.6%, Consumer Staples  0%, Energy  0.4%, Financials  0.3%, Health Care  1.2%, Industrials  0.4%, Information Technology  -0.9%, Materials  0.7%, Telecommunication Services  -1%, Utilities  0.1%

* EARNINGS: Alphabet (GOOGL) weighed on tech and wider indices after a disappointing Q3 EPS figure, with its Other Bets segment’s profitability falling further. Health care titans Pfizer (PFE) and Merck (MRK) supported the sector after stellar earnings reports and guidance. Grubhub (GRUB) lost close to half its market cap after grim guidance and admittance to a struggling business model, also weighing on competitor Uber (UBER). Beyond Meat (BYND) lost a fifth of its market cap despite a forecast beating earnings report as investors raised concerns on its stretched valuation. T-Mobile (TMUS) came under pressure following a miss on revenue, with the Sprint (S) merger question still an overhang. NXP Semiconductors (NXPI) spiked after beating top and bottom line estimates and raising its dividend by 50%, although the wider SOX sector traded subdued as the wider tech sector came under pressure. General Motors (GM) opened firmer after strong Q3 earnings, despite lower than expected guidance in wake of the UAW strike. Shopify (SHOP) opened lower after a surprise loss-per-share. Mastercard (MA) edged higher, where it beat consensus estimates but did warn of higher operating expenses going forward. Also surging on earnings were Texas Roadhouse (TXRH), Xerox (XRX), National Oilwell (NOV), Leggett & Platt (LEG) Leidos (LDOS), HCA Healthcare (HCA), Incyte (INCY), Ingersoll-Rand (IR), Marsh & McLennan (MMC) and Kellogg (K). Conversely, IPG Photonics (IPGP), Waters (WAT), A. O. Smith (AOS), Corning (GLW), SBA Communications (SBAC), Peabody Energy (BTU) were under pressure from their earnings reports.

* STOCK SPECIFICS: Fiat Chrysler (FCAU) had a late day spike into the green after the WSJ reported it was in talks with Peugeot (UG FP) for a USD 50bln merger. Tesla (TSLA) sold off on its 10-Q filing where investors scrutinised its reporting, particularly the decline in quarterly domestic sales; Roth downgraded the stock to Sell citing warranty adjustments as a large driver of the margin beat, something that is unsustainable. Mirati Therapeutics (MRTX) spiked on a positive data from tumour treatment, MRTX849. PG&E (PCG) pared some of its heavy losses as it restored power to more customers. Walmart (WMT) was the victim of Amazon’s (AMZN) free grocery delivery for Prime members announcement. Apache (APA) traded higher after a Sector Weight initiation at KeyBanc, citing an improving growth story.

* WTI (Z9) SETTLED USD 0.27 LOWER AT USD 55.54/BBL; BRENT (F0) SETTLED USD 0.02 LOWER AT USD 61.23/BBL: The crude complex mirrored equities in US trading hours, rising with the latter after US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin comments re. looser bank rules spurred risk sentiment. However, the complex has failed to fully recover from overnight/European morning losses and is still marginally lower on the day. Citi posit that the market may have already priced in a build in US commercial crude stocks for last week, but caveat that there could yet be further reaction as the actual data is reported. Others have noted continued Russian reluctance amid ongoing discussion on whether OPEC+ producers will be able to agree on deeper production cuts at the group’s next summit December 5th to 6th in Vienna. The Saudis appear ready to reduce output further, notes Citi, but they caveat that these positions are quite similar to a year ago, when a similar dance led to a last-minute agreement to cut for 2019, with Russia allowed to phase in compliance gradually. The bank cautions that there’s no guarantee of a repeat, but wouldn’t rule out a similar outcome for 2020, although slowing US production growth is a complicating factor for any decision making. Ahead of the API US energy inventory data on Tuesday evening and official EIA release on Wednesday, crude stocks are seen building 0.5mln bbls, gasoline drawing 2.4mln bbls and distillates drawing 2.4mln bbls.

* US T-NOTE (Z9) SETTLED 3+ TICKS HIGHER AT 129-08+. Albeit thin ranges, the TPLEX made headway as investors grew cautious amid talk of a delay to the US-China Phase 1 deal. The (small) lion’s share of the move came in the European session when major equity bourses began their trundle lower in anticipation of key risk events. There was a ramp up of corporate issuance on Tuesday, with ten issuers scheduled to hit the primary IG market - including a USD 4bln M&A bond from Danaher (DHR) - potentially providing resistance to the wider debt complex. At settlement the curve was fractionally flatter with the 10-year yield down 1.8bps and the 2-year yield down 0.8bps, with participants now looking towards the FOMC on Wednesday.

* FX WRAP:DXY saw choppy trade today where it initially traded firmer in the morning as GBP and EUR declined, however the gains were shortlived as the buck reversed its climb which was further boosted by weaker Consumer Confidence data which eventually saw DXY hit lows of 97.606 from highs of 97.93 as participants now await tomorrow’s Fed interest rate decision and Friday’s NFP report. GBP traded sideways today as UK is heading to the polls with tonight's early election bill passing. GBPUSD topped out at the psychological 1.29 level and sold off back to 1.2850 in the later half of trade, where desks note the level seemed rather stable in the morning, potentially magnetising the cross back to it.  Havens, traded relatively flat today although caught a slight bid once it was announced that China and the US may not sign a deal at the Chile meeting, although the whole release of the report did state that the two still expect to sign it here, USDJPY traded in tight ranges today from 109.06 at the highs as the cross found resistance at the 200dma (109.05) to 108.78 at the lows. CHF traded flat against USD, GBP and EUR. XAU remains beneath the 1500 level on Tuesday also. Flanking the G10 rankings are AUD, the Scandis and CAD; the former firmer despite reiterative comments from RBA Governor Lower reinforcing a readiness to cut the OCR again if needed, the Scandis weighed on by shifts in Norges Bank and Riksbank policy outlooks beyond normalisation cycles and the latter lower on falling WTI prices and ahead of tomorrow’s BoC meeting. NZD is flat and lags its antipodean counterpart following warnings from the NZ Treasury about S&P downgrading its positive ratings outlook due to higher budget spending. In EMFX, ZAR is weaker but trying to stage a recovery, after plans unveiled to rescue Eskom failed to highlight debt restructuring, but subsequent statements from the Finance Minister did pledge to ensure no default. ARS is slightly lower, after making decent gains yesterday following yesterday’s imposition of capital controls.

subject: Daily FX Wrap: DXY shies away from 98.000 as the clock ticks down to the Fed
content:
USD

Choppy trade in the currency markets amidst fluctuating risk sentiment and more mixed US data ahead of the FOMC rate call and accompanying statement on Wednesday, with consumer confidence confounding expectations for a decent improvement, but sentiment still a shade better than previously. However, the Dollar’s moves were largely a function of external price action and direction, as the index got to within a whisker of 98.000 at one stage when G10 rivals were floundering or handing back relative gains before fading when counterparts regrouped and/or rebounded quite firmly in some cases. DXY now holding just above a 97.637 base.

AUD/NZD

The Aussie has emerged as the major front-runner having overcome a wobble in wake of comments from RBA Governor Lower reinforcing a readiness to cut the OCR again, if needed, with Aud/Usd edging further above 0.6850 and the Aud/Nzd cross revisiting 1.0800 ahead of Aussie CPI overnight. Conversely, the Kiwi is still lagging around 0.6350 against its US peer following warnings from the NZ Treasury about S&P downgrading its positive ratings outlook due to higher budget spending.

GBP/EUR

A bit more tandem trading on breaking Brexit/UK political headlines and reports awaiting PM Johnson’s latest push for an early December GE that seemed more attainable in simple maths terms compared to the task last night that fell well short of the 2/3 majority, but could yet be derailed by amendments – check our headline feed for latest/updated analysis at 15.30GMT. Nevertheless, Cable is hovering much closer to Wednesday’s EU session highs than lows within a circa 1.2807-99 range, while Eur/Gbp is back down around the middle of its 0.8651-08 parameters even though the single currency is faring well vs the flagging Greenback with Eur/Usd inching above 1.1100 again.

CHF/JPY/CAD 

The Franc, Yen and Loonie all remain rangebound and narrowly mixed against the Buck, as Usd/Chf rotates around 0.9850 after SNB reminders about the value of NIRP and direct FX intervention to curb excess Franc appreciation/demand, Usd/Jpy hovers just below 109.00 and Usd/Cad straddles 1.3050 ahead of the BoC, Fed and BoJ in chronological order.

NOK/SEK/ZAR 

All on the back foot, with the Scandi Kronas undermined by shifts in Norges Bank and Riksbank policy outlooks beyond normalisation cycles (ending in September and December respectively), while the Rand is trying to pare losses made after plans unveiled to rescue Eskom failed to highlight debt restructuring, but subsequent statements from the Finance Minister did pledge to ensure no default.

BREXIT UPDATE: Johnson's fourth election vote set to pass, but could be scuppered by hostile amendments
content:
* THE LATEST: Last night, the UK Parliament rejected PM Johnson's FTPA motion for an early election as expected, with 299 MP's voting in favour, short of the two-thirds (434) majority needed. Immediately after, UK PM Johnson gave notice that he will introduce a short bill for an election on December 12th, which would only require a simple majority but could be subject to amendments. Reportedly, Labour will back the government's bill to hold an election in early December regardless of the date, while the Liberal Democrats, have also indicated they will support the bill, as long as the government fulfils three conditions including ruling out no deal (fulfilled now there is an extension in place), dropping the WAB (note: the Lib Dems are an anti-Brexit party and, according to hypothetical polling, their support looks set to decline if the UK actually leaves the EU) and “setting the date in stone”. Hence, the bill looks set to pass and an early December election a done deal. 

* AMENDMENTS: Midday Tuesday, UK lawmakers voted in favour of the Creasy amendment to the government's early election bill, which allows further amendments. The passing of this amendment opens the door to further amendments of the government's early election bill: Labour and the SNP are now pushing amendments to allow 16/17 year-olds and EU nationals to vote in the election (these two groups tend to lean heavily left/pro-remain). However, current expectations are that these amendments will not garner enough votes - the Lib Dems appear to have made a "pact" of sort with the government along the lines of the government dropping the WAB (ensuring the UK doesn't leave the EU before an election, which favours the Lib Dems) and compromising on the date of the election to hold it slightly earlier in exchange for the Lib Dems not backing any "hostile amendments" such as those detailed above. It is unclear how groups such as the DUP will vote. There is also an argument that logistically it will be impossible to register all of those extra voters prior in time for a December general election. However, if such amendments were to pass, the government has said it will pull the early election bill in its entirety, and may return to pushing for the passing of WAB. In terms of the amendment to the election's date, government sources indicated that it is willing to compromise and may accept an amendment that moves the date of the election forward one day to the 11th of December, a date which Labour has also indicated it will support. 

With the opposition on board, the government's bill is expected to pass the House of Commons today, and could move to the House of Lords tomorrow, meaning the government could have secured an election by as soon as Thursday. For reference, the latest polling from YouGov gives the Conservative Party a commanding lead at 36%, Labour at 23%, Liberal Democrats at 18% and the Brexit Party at 12%. It is worth noting however, that translating national polling figures into parliamentary seats is difficult given the UK's first past the post system; a commonly used example is UKIP in the 2017 election; over 3 million voted for the party yet it won one seat in parliament. 

* TODAY’S TIMINGS:

16:30GMT onwards: Second Reading Vote for the government one-line bill for an election on December 12th.

18:30GMT onwards: Final vote on the bill.

Note: MP's will be denied individual votes on amendments in the scenario that there are too many, they will instead be put together into combined votes.

subject: PREVIEW: FOMC rate decision (October 2019)
content:
• The Fed is expected to lower rates by 25bps to 1.50-1.75%; key will be whether the Committee signals that it is now on pause, or whether the door to further cuts remains open. While market pricing and the analyst consensus are looking for a rate cut, some have warned that there may be enough for the Fed to pause at this meeting. The FOMC will publish its rate decision on 31st October 2019 at 1800 GMT/1400 EDT. Post-meeting press conference with Fed Chair Powell scheduled for 1830 GMT/1430 EDT. RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 29th October 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • European bourses are softer after a relatively flat open, as newsflow remains light ahead of the weeks risk events
  • UK Opposition Labour Party are to back a December election, irrespective of the date
  • US House Speaker Pelosi announced in a letter to Democrats that the House will vote to formalize the procedures related to impeachment inquiry of President Trump
  • Looking ahead highlights include, US Consumer Confidence & Pending Home Sales, BoE's Carney
  • Earnings: Pfizer, Amgen, AMD, Mastercard

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets trade mixed as the region just about took impetus from Wall St where the S&P 500 and NASDAQ 100 notched record highs after US-China trade optimism was further fuelled by comments from US President Trump that suggested a signing of the phase 1 deal could be ahead of schedule. ASX 200 (U/C) was lifted at the open although some of the gains were later faded amid losses in commodity stocks due to lower oil prices and after the precious metal gave up the USD 1500/oz level, while Nikkei 225 (+0.5%) briefly reclaimed the 23000 milestone for the first time in over a year as it benefitted from a more favourable currency. Conversely, Hang Seng (-0.4%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.9%) were the laggards despite the current backdrop of heightened trade optimism, as participants digested a slew of earnings and after the PBoC refrained from liquidity operations which resulted to a substantial CNY 250bln liquidity drain. Finally, 10yr JGBs tracked the losses in T-notes amid gains in stocks and with the Japanese benchmark at a yearly high, although some of the losses were recouped following a predominantly stronger than previous 2yr JGB auction results.

PBoC skipped open market operations for a net daily drain of CNY 250bln. (Newswires)

PBoC set CNY mid-point at 7.0617 vs. Exp. 7.0604 (Prev. 7.0762)

Tokyo CPI (Oct) Y/Y 0.4% vs. Exp. 0.7% (Prev. 0.4%). (Newswires) Tokyo CPI Ex. Fresh Food (Oct) Y/Y 0.5% vs. Exp. 0.7% (Prev. 0.6%) Tokyo CPI Ex. Fresh Food & Energy (Oct) Y/Y 0.7% vs. Exp. 0.7% (Prev. 0.5%)

US

US House Speaker Pelosi announced in a letter to Democrats that the House will vote to formalize the procedures related to impeachment inquiry of President Trump. (FT)

GEOPOLITICS

Northern Hong Kong residents are reportedly demanding authorities investigate a 'suspicious smell' which may be tear gas or shooting practices relating to the Peoples Liberation Army (PLA); said to have sparked further protests on Tuesday., SCMP. (Newswires)

UK/EU

Tentative UK Parliament Schedule for Today’s Election bill:

- 16:30GMT onwards, Second Reading Vote

- 18:30GMT onwards, Final Vote

- Note, MP’s will be denied individual votes on amendments in the scenario that there are too many, they will instead be put together into combined votes.   Mirror’s Bloom (Twitter)

Labour are to back a bill for a December election, regardless of the date. (Twitter/Newswires)

UK Downing Street sources say they would accept an SNP/Lib Dem amendment to allow an election to take place on December 11th, according to PoliticsHome's Schofield. (Twitter)

Several cabinet sources prefer to push through the WAB rather than holding an election, an opinion shared by many Conservative MPs, says BBC's Hawkins. (Newswires)

UK Liberal Democrat Leader Swinson said the reason for seeking a December 9th election is to ensure Brexiteers have no time to push through the Brexit deal; adding, even if PM Johnson gave assurances not to reintroduce the WAB during the election bill period she would not trust this. (BBC/Newswires) BBC political correspondent Nick Eardley tweeted that he is hearing the government will attempt to force election bill through various commons stages today. (Twitter/BBC)

EQUITIES

European equities have drifted lower after a relatively uninspiring open [Eurostoxx -0.3%] following on from a mixed APAC. Bourses are broadly in the red and remain choppy with no clear underperformer, albeit the region remains cautious ahead of this week’s risk events. Sectors are mostly in negative territory with the exception of Healthcare, which is buoyed by Fresenius SE (+4.5%) and Fresenius Medical Care (+5.8%) after earnings topped analyst estimates. On the flip side, the energy sector bears the brunt of softer energy prices coupled with overall downbeat numbers from oil-giant BP (-2.2%) who reported a 41% drop in Q3 net profits due to lower upstream earnings, softer oil prices, maintenance and weather impacts. Individual movers are largely earnings orientated, Grifols (+3.2%) benefit following firm earnings coupled with a EUR 5.3bln refinancing programme whilst to the downside, Stora Enso (-8%) shares plumbed the depths after disappointing earnings in which the Co. cited weak Q4 demand, thus peers Smurfit Kappa (-0.5%) and Mondi (-0.3%) initial fell in sympathy but has since trimmed losses. Finally, Swedbank (-3.8%) sunk after Estonian Financial Inspector and Sweden’s FSA opened sanctioning cases regarding the Co’s alleged money laundering. Looking ahead to US earnings, Dow listed Merck & Co (2.1% weighting) and Pfzier (0.9% weighting) which may have follow-through effects to European peers.

Sony (6758 JT) are to invest nearly USD 1bln on image sensor production in Japan, according to Nikkei. (Nikkei)

BP (BP/ LN) – Q3 adj. net USD 2.25bln vs. Exp. USD 1.77bln, revenue USD 68.29bln vs. Prev. USD 72.67bln, underlying replacement cost profit USD 2.3bln vs. Prev. USD 3.8bln, replacement cost (RC) loss USD 0.351bln vs. Prev. profit USD 3.091bln. FY19 Capex guidance midpoint cut to under USD 16bln vs. Prev. guidance. USD 15-17bln; Prev. YY USD 15.1bln. Note divestments are ahead of schedule, downstream expansion in fast-growing markets; adding that Q3 saw lower oil and gas prices and the hurricane impacts were significant. Q3 dividend of USD 0.1025/shr, scrip dividend alternative has been suspended for Q3. (Newswires)

Merck & Co Inc (MRK) Q3 19 (USD): Adj EPS 1.51 (exp. 1.24), Revenue 12.4bln (exp. 11.63bln); narrows and raises FY revenue range to 46.5-47bln (exp. 45.99bln)

Pfizer Inc (PFE) Q3 19 (USD): Adj. EPS 0.75 (exp. 0.62), Revenue 12.7bln (exp. 12.26bln). FY EPS view 2.94-3.00 (exp. 2.82), Raise midpoint of guidance range by 200mln driven by a 400mln operational improvement.

Alphabet Inc (GOOGL) reported Q3 EPS USD 10.12 vs. Exp. USD 12.39, Revenue USD 40.5bln vs. Exp. USD 40.32bln. (Newswires) Co. shares fell 1.6% aftermarket.

FX

GBP - The Pound was initially precarious after the latest Parliament rejection of a motion to hold a GE on December 12 and ongoing wrangle to find an alternative date that might garner enough backing between Downing Street and those opposition parties that are likely to vote in favour of a snap poll. However, Labour subsequently giving their support to a December General Election has generated Sterling strength with Cable now firmer on the day with a high circa 1.2870 thus far.

USD - Sterling weakness and some contagion has nudged the DXY a tad closer to 98.000 ahead of more US data and day 1 of the October FOMC meeting that is widely expected to culminate in a 3rd 25 bp rate cut, but probably highlight ongoing divergence between Fed policy-makers resulting in less clarity over forward guidance.

EUR/CHF/NZD/CAD - All softer vs the Greenback, as the single currency remains top heavy around 1.1100, but underpinned ahead of Fib support at 1.1065, while the Franc continues to pivot 0.9950, Kiwi straddles 0.6350 and Loonie meander either side of 1.3050.

AUD/JPY - Bucking the overall trend, albeit marginally and also largely rangebound awaiting this week’s big events that kick off from Wednesday. The Aussie is still outpacing is US and NZ peers as Aud/Usd hovers around 0.6850 and Aud/Nzd just shy of 1.0800, but not deriving much impetus via comments from RBA Governor Lowe broadly reaffirming the on hold for now with an easing bias stance. However, looming CPI data could well be influential ahead of housing metrics on Thursday and PPI the following day. Elsewhere, the Yen has pared some losses from a test of 200 DMA support at 109.06 and decent option expiry interest from 109.00 to 109.10 (1.6 bn) even though Japan Post Insurance is eyeing less JGB holdings in the October-March period.

NOK - The Norwegian Crown is underperforming and only just holding off fresh record lows vs the Euro circa 10.2575 amidst softer crude prices and Norges Bank rhetoric underlining that rates are likely to remain unchanged for the entire forecast horizon, or coming period to quote Nicolaisen verbatim.

EM - The Rand has rapidly depreciated in wake of outlines of the SA Government’s plan for Eskom that did not include debt restructuring and propelled Usd/Zar up sharply towards 14.7200 vs near 14.5300 at one stage.

South African government plan has no new information on debt restructuring for state-owned utility company Eskom and sees separate transmission units. New CEO to be announced next week, Co. aims to cut fuel costs break up the monopoly and increase output of renewables (Newswires)

RBA Governor Lowe reiterates the Central Bank is prepared to ease further if needed and sees a gentle turning point in the economy, it is extraordinarily unlikely we will see negative interest rates in Australia. (Newswires)

Notable FX Expiries, NY Cut:

- USD/JPY: 108.00-05 (1.1BLN), 108.50 (360M), 109.00-10 (1.6BLN)

FIXED INCOME

A solid enough uptake for UK linkers may have been discounted given ongoing Brexit uncertainly and potential inflation implications, but the recovery in debt markets was already gathering more momentum regardless. Indeed, Bunds, Gilts and 10 year US T-notes extended their rebounds to 171.07, 132.13 and 129-11 respectively before running out of steam approaching yesterday’s intraday peaks. Ahead, US housing data and APIs as the clock ticks down to the start of the Fed policy meeting and business end of the week.

COMMODITIES                                      

WTI and Brent are softer this morning but once again not by any significant magnitude trading with losses of less that USD 1/bbl at present. News flow for the session thus far has again been light though this is likely to pick up from tomorrow via data and Central Bank meetings, including FOMC. For the rest of the session the main highlight will be tonight’s APIs which previously printed a build of 4.51mln and was notably not corroborated by the subsequent EIA metrics showing a draw of 1.69mln. Elsewhere, source reports note that Saudi Aramco is to announce the price range on November 17th and begin an IPO subscription on December 4th, aiming to trade on the Saudi Market from December 11th. Further, Nigeria’s new Energy Minister was on the wires this morning, albeit provided little by way of new substance. Elsewhere, gold prices remain tentative within a tight range, as is usually the case ahead of the Fed’s monetary policy meeting; however, the metal has just seen a modest sell off. Meanwhile, copper trimmed some of yesterday’s losses, again on the lookout for risk events. Finally, Dalian iron ore futures ended the day lower by 1.7% amid China demand woes.

Saudi Aramco is to reportedly announce price range on November 17th, start subscription for IPO on December 4th and trade on the Saudi stock market on December 11th, sources state. (Newswires)

A solid enough uptake for UK linkers may have been discounted given ongoing Brexit uncertainly and potential inflation implications, but the recovery in debt markets was already gathering more momentum regardless. Indeed, Bunds, Gilts and 10 year US T-notes extended their rebounds to 171.07, 132.13 and 129-11 respectively before running out of steam approaching yesterday’s intraday peaks. Ahead, US housing data and APIs as the clock ticks down to the start of the Fed policy meeting and business end of the week.

COMMODITIES                                      

WTI and Brent are softer this morning but once again not by any significant magnitude trading with losses of less than USD 1/bbl at present. News flow for the session thus far has again been light though this is likely to pick up from tomorrow via data and Central Bank meetings, including FOMC. For the rest of the session the main highlight will be tonight’s APIs which previously printed a build of 4.51mln and was notably not corroborated by the subsequent EIA metrics showing a draw of 1.69mln. Elsewhere, source reports note that Saudi Aramco is to announce the price range on November 17th and begin an IPO subscription on December 4th, aiming to trade on the Saudi Market from December 11th. Further, Nigeria’s new Energy Minister was on the wires this morning, albeit provided little by way of new substance. Elsewhere, gold prices initially remained within a tight range, although the yellow metal experienced some selling pressure in recent trade with little by way of immediate fundamental catalysts. Meanwhile, copper trimmed some of yesterday’s losses, again on the lookout for risk events. Finally, Dalian iron ore futures ended the day lower by 1.7% amid China demand woes.

subject: Nomura Quants: Potential for upside in rates as long bond positions are pared
content:
• Many investors appear to be reevaluating their overly conservative investment stances and short-term supply-demand dynamics in equity markets may have taken a favorable turn in most regions, not just in the US.
  • The pick-up in risk appetite also appears to have filtered through to bond markets, with a shift towards high-yield bonds away from sovereign bonds seemingly underway.
  • Over the past year, CTAs building up notable long bond future positions over the past year. However, CTAs have now cut these positions by around 40-50% from the peak levels seen in the summer of 2019. Nomura sees the potential for further reduction in longs in order to avoid losses in the face of waning upward momentum for bond prices.
  • In terms of levels to watch out for, Nomura see potential triggers in the 10yr UST a 1.76% (the average cost of CTA’s net purchases since June), 1.9% (cost since April) and circa 2.05% (typical cost since March). Nomura notes that a move above 2.05% could see yields spike up to around 2.5%.
  • Elsewhere, CTAs have closed out around 80% of their long positions (from 26th August peak) in Bund futures with potential trigger levels in yields at -0.34% and -0.18%; a break above the latter level could push yields to circa 0.2%. For UK paper, CTAs have closed out around 55% of their long positions (from 22nd August peak) in Gilt futures with potential trigger levels in yields at 0.74% and -0.85%; a break above the latter level could push yields to circa 1.2%. For JGBs, CTAs have closed out around 40% of their long positions (from 28th August peak) with potential trigger levels in yields at -0.11% and -0.08%; a break above the latter level could push yields to circa 0.1%.
  • Overall, Nomura believes that “the risk of an extreme mechanistic sell-off of bond futures that ignores the economic facts on the ground is unlikely to materialize”.

Asian equity markets trade mostly higher as the region just about took impetus from Wall St where the S&P 500 and NASDAQ 100 notched record highs after US-China trade optimism was further fuelled by comments from US President Trump that suggested a signing of the phase 1 deal could be ahead of schedule.   • Asian equity markets trade mostly higher as the region just about took impetus from Wall St where the S&P 500 and NASDAQ 100 notched record highs
  • USTR office is to consider extensions of certain tariff exclusions on USD 34bln of Chinese goods from November 1st
  • UK lawmakers rejected PM Johnson's request for an early election with 299 MP's voting in favour, short of the two-thirds (434) majority needed
  • UK PM Johnson will now give notice of a short bill (requires a simple majority but can be subject to amendments) for an election on December 12th
  • Looking ahead, highlights include US Consumer Confidence & Pending Home Sales, BoE's Carney
  • Earnings: Pfizer, Amgen, AMD, Mastercard, BP, Fresenius SE, Fresenius Medical

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets trade mostly higher as the region just about took impetus from Wall St where the S&P 500 and NASDAQ 100 notched record highs after US-China trade optimism was further fuelled by comments from US President Trump that suggested a signing of the phase 1 deal could be ahead of schedule. ASX 200 (+0.1%) was lifted at the open although some of the gains were later faded amid losses in commodity stocks due to lower oil prices and after the precious metal gave up the USD 1500/oz level, while Nikkei 225 (+0.4%) briefly reclaimed the 23000 milestone for the first time in over a year as it benefitted from a more favourable currency. Conversely, Hang Seng (-0.5%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.6%) were the laggards despite the current backdrop of heightened trade optimism, as participants digested a slew of earnings and after the PBoC refrained from liquidity operations which resulted to a substantial CNY 250bln liquidity drain. Finally, 10yr JGBs tracked the losses in T-notes amid gains in stocks and with the Japanese benchmark at a yearly high, although some of the losses were recouped following a predominantly stronger than previous 2yr JGB auction results.

 

PBoC skipped open market operations for a net daily drain of CNY 250bln. (Newswires)

PBoC set CNY mid-point at 7.0617 vs. Exp. 7.0604 (Prev. 7.0762)

 

USTR office is to consider extensions of certain tariff exclusions on USD 34bln of Chinese goods from November 1st, while it added the exclusions on certain tariffs are set to expire on December 28th and an extension would be for a year. (Newswires)

US FCC will vote in November to prohibit companies from using government programme funds to purchase equipment from companies deemed as a national security risk, while reports added the FCC will designate Huawei and ZTE as such companies which would give them 30 days to contest the designation. (Newswires) Tokyo CPI (Oct) Y/Y 0.4% vs. Exp. 0.7% (Prev. 0.4%). (Newswires) Tokyo CPI Ex. Fresh Food (Oct) Y/Y 0.5% vs. Exp. 0.7% (Prev. 0.6%) Tokyo CPI Ex. Fresh Food & Energy (Oct) Y/Y 0.7% vs. Exp. 0.7% (Prev. 0.5%)

UK/EU

UK PM Johnson said in a letter to EU Council President that the UK has accepted the EU's extension offer (as mandated by the Benn Act) and expressed that it is against his wishes. (Newswires)

UK lawmakers rejected PM Johnson's request for an early election with 299 MP's voting in favour, short of the two-thirds (434) majority needed. Following the defeat, UK PM Johnson said we will not allow this paralysis to continue and will give notice of a short bill (requires a simple majority but can be subject to amendments) for an election on December 12th, while the government confirmed it will not try again to bring the WAB back and that it did not agree on the Liberal Democrats date on the 9th as they are not sure they can get the bill through in time. (Newswires/BBC) Liberal Democrat Leader Swinson said the reason for seeking a December 9th election is to ensure Brexiteers have no time to push through the Brexit deal; adding, even if PM Johnson gave assurances not to reintroduce the WAB during the election bill period she would not trust this. (BBC/Newswires) BBC political correspondent Nick Eardley tweeted that he is hearing the government will attempt to force election bill through various commons stages today. (Twitter/BBC) 

FX

DXY was flat and stuck to within the thin range from the prior US session with a non-committal tone seen as we approach closer to this week’s blockbuster risk events stateside, while its major counterparts were also uneventful in which EUR/USD treaded water around 1.1100 and with GBP/USD partially reversed some of the support from the EU’s approval of the 3-month Brexit “flextension”. USD/JPY and JPY-crosses held on to recent gains amid the mostly positive risk tone and after softer than expected Tokyo inflation despite this month’s sales tax increase, while antipodeans were firmer as they benefit from their high-beta properties and after the PBoC strengthened the CNY reference rate setting.

 

New Zealand Treasury sees risk of S&P removing positive Outlook on its rating following increased social spending in recent “Wellbeing Budget”. (Newswires) COMMODITIES

Commodities were subdued in which WTI crude futures languished firmly below the USD 56.00/bbl level after the prior day’s losses where oil prices failed to benefit from the heightened trade optimism and instead gave back some of its recent gains on book squaring heading into month end and expiry of Brent Dec. 2019 options yesterday, while focus now shifts to the inventory reports beginning with APIs later where a narrow build in crude stockpiles of 0.7mln bbls is anticipated. Elsewhere, gold traded lacklustre after its retreat below the USD 1500/oz with the looming FOMC restricting price action, and copper also reflected the despondent tone across the complex, as well as the underperformance in China.

Saudi Energy Minister Prince Abdulaziz bin Salman and Nigeria Energy Minister Sylva discussed oil markets and joint cooperation between the OPEC+ members to maintain market stability. (Newswires)

 

GEOPOLITICS

Israeli military increased its readiness and adjusted air defences in preparation for a potential Iranian cruise missile or suicide drone attack. (ELINT News)

US The pick-up in risk appetite saw rates continue to backup to start the week. The TPLEX trundled lower throughout the European session and remained at lows in the US session whilst participants pushed US equity bourses to new ATHs. The US Treasury announced it expects to issue USD 352bln (Prior estimate 381bln) in net marketable debt in Q4 19, and USD 389bln in Q1 20, saying it borrowed USD 440bln in Q3 19. By settlement the curve had mainly bear steepened, with both 2s10s and 2s30s 2.5bps wider, with the 2-year yield up by 2bps. US T-note (z9) settled 12 ticks lower at 129-05.

 

US House Speaker Pelosi announced in a letter to Democrats that the House will vote to formalize the procedures related to impeachment inquiry of President Trump. (FT)

subject: ASIA-PAC MARKET WRAP: Asia traded mostly higher after further trade optimism propelled Wall St to record highs, although China underperformed amid earnings deluge and liquidity drain
content: Asia equity markets trade mostly higher as the region just about took impetus from Wall St where the S&P 500 and NASDAQ 100 notched record highs after US-China trade optimism was further fuelled by comments from US President Trump that suggested a signing of the phase 1 deal could be ahead of schedule. ASX 200 (+0.1%) was lifted at the open although some of the gains were later faded amid losses in commodity stocks due to lower oil prices and after the precious metal gave up the USD 1500/oz level, while Nikkei 225 (+0.4%) briefly reclaimed the 23000 milestone for the first time in over a year as it benefitted from a more favourable currency. Conversely, Hang Seng (-0.5%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.6%) were the laggards despite the current backdrop of heightened trade optimism, as participants digested a slew of earnings and after the PBoC refrained from liquidity operations which resulted to a substantial CNY 250bln liquidity drain. Finally, 10yr JGBs tracked the losses in T-notes amid gains in stocks and with the Japanese benchmark at a yearly high, although some of the losses were recouped following a predominantly stronger than previous 2yr JGB auction results.

ASIA-PAC MID-SESSION UPDATE: Asia trades mostly higher after trade optimism fuelled Wall St to record highs, although China lags amid earnings and liquidity outflows
content:
Asia equity markets trade mostly higher as the region attempts to sustain the impetus from Wall St where the S&P 500 and NASDAQ 100 notched record highs after US-China trade optimism was further fuelled by comments from US President Trump that suggested a signing of the phase 1 deal could be ahead of schedule. ASX 200 (+0.1%) was lifted at the open although some of the gains were later faded amid losses in commodity stocks due to lower oil prices and after the precious metal gave up the USD 1500/oz level, while Nikkei 225 (+0.5%) briefly reclaimed the 23000 milestone for the first time in over a year as it benefits from a more favourable currency. Hang Seng (-0.1%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.3%) are the laggards despite the current backdrop of heightened trade optimism, with participants digesting a slew of earnings and after the PBoC refrained from liquidity operations which resulted to a substantial CNY 250bln liquidity drain.

In FX markets, the DXY is flat and has stuck to within the thin range from the prior US session with a non-committal tone seen as we approach closer to this week’s blockbuster risk events stateside, while its major counterparts are also uneventful with EUR/USD treading water around 1.1100 and with GBP/USD partially reversing some of the support from the EU’s approval of the 3-month Brexit “flextension”. Furthermore, UK PM Johnson’s request for an election was rejected by Parliament as expected, but he will attempt again with one-line bill today to change the law and get around the two-thirds majority needed for an early election. Elsewhere, USD/JPY and JPY-crosses hold on to recent gains amid the mostly positive risk tone and after softer than expected Tokyo inflation despite this month’s sales tax increase, while antipodeans are firmer as they benefit from their high-beta properties and after the PBoC strengthened the CNY reference rate setting.

Finally, 10yr JGBs tracked the losses in T-notes amid gains in stocks and with the Japanese benchmark at a yearly high, while demand for JGBs is also subdued ahead of a 2yr JGB auction later.
